contextId.information: This refers to the whole day. The writer speaks of the whole day as if it were these two parts. In the Jewish culture, a day begins when the sun sets. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. AT: "everything, including both good and evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

Here "good and evil" is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. See how you translated "knowledge of good and evil" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:09|2:9]]. AT: "knowing everything, including both good and evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

Here "good and evil" is a figure of speech that refers to both extremes and everything in between. See how you translated "knowledge of good and evil" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:02:09|2:9]]. AT: "knowing everything, including both good and evil"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

"the God of heaven and earth." The words "heaven" and "earth" are used together to mean every thing that God created. AT: "the God of everything in heaven and earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: the God of heaven and the God of the earth

contextId.information: The words "good nor bad" are used together to mean "anything." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:31:24|31:24]]. AT: "Do not say anything to try and stop Jacob from leaving" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: Be careful that you speak to Jacob neither good nor bad
